Project Number: 46179  
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
December 2012 
 
 
 
Enhancing Capacity for Effective Project 
Implementation

members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Country portfolio review missions and regular project supervision missions continue to 
observe delays in project implementation caused by executing agency’s lack of understanding 
and familiarity with the project implementation procedures of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB). This includes procurement and consulting policies and difficulties in terms of project and 
contract  management  during  implementation.  Discussions  have  been  held  with  regional 
departments and these have highlighted the need for the ADB Central Operations Services 
Office (COSO) to lead a technical assistance (TA) project that would help provide support to 
ADB’s  developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  in  this  respect.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The  regional  departments  have  highlighted  lack  of  capacity  for  effective  project 
implementation as a constraint for good project performance.   ADB is providing increased 
support to its DMCs—the active portfolio on 31 December 2011 totaled $58.8 billion, $4.9 billion 
(9%) more than its value a year earlier. The number of projects increased from 576 projects to 
612 projects over the same period. As ADB's operations have increased, the complexity of the 
projects and the modalities offered have also increased. At the same time, ADB is operating in 
new  sectors,  and  in  remote  and  poor  areas  of  countries  where  capacity  for  project 
implementation is weak. All of these factors affect the overall quality of project implementation. 
 
3.  The  Development  Effectiveness  Review2 also  shows  that,  while  project  outputs  for 
2009–2011 remained on track for ADB operations, project delays and cancellations resulted in 
lower output delivery, in particular for Asian Development Fund operations. Even the best 
designed  project  will  fail  to  deliver  results  if  implementation  falls  short.  The  2011  Annual 
Portfolio Performance Report3 notes that implementation is delayed by poor quality procurement 
plans and poor contract packaging, which results in significant administrative cost to ADB and 
executing agencies. ADB’s Strategy 2020 identifies capacity development as a driver of change 
that provides ADB with an opportunity to be an active and supportive development partner.4  
 
4.  In June 2010, a project implementation working group was established with a mandate 
to identify key issues and regional department good practices that could be replicated or applied 
more  widely  across  ADB  to  improve  project  implementation.  The  good  practices  and 
recommendations were identified under three themes: (i) achieving total project readiness, (ii) 
enhancing  organization,  staff  skills  and  incentives,  and  (iii)  ensuring  effective  project 
implementation.5 To respond to the latter, this regional TA will support project cycle capacity 
development of executing agencies, including increased implementation capacity and project 
management skills.  
 
5.  The  regional  TA  puts  effective  project  implementation  at  the  core  of  good  project 
management and provides capacity building support for project implementation. Since 1978, 
ADB  has  funded  project  implementation  and  administration  seminars  with  TA  grants  to 
strengthen the capacity of borrowers and executing agencies to manage projects financed by

ADB. Senior and mid-level officials of executing agencies, central ministries, state banks, and 
state and provincial governments from 34 DMCs have participated in and benefited from these 
seminars, which have centered on policies and procedures for the procurement of goods, works, 
and consulting services, project and contract management, and for disbursement of loan and 
grant proceeds. 
 
6.  There is a need to develop high-quality training programs with a new approach that will 
increase capacity for effective project implementation (see paragraph 9 and 10). Such capacity 
development  support  will  lead  to  effective  and  efficient  project  management.  The  TA  will 
leverage  existing  regional  department  initiatives  for  increased  capacity  for  project 
implementation and knowledge of the DMCs, and share lessons in project implementation from 
other countries.6 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The expected impact of the regional TA is effective project implementation in selected 
DMCs. The TA outcome will be improved capacity of executing agencies in implementing ADB-
financed projects in selected DMCs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will deliver training programs to EAs’ staff working on ongoing and future ADB-
financed projects. The output of the TA is ‘good quality training programs are delivered in key 
developing member countries up to 2014’. Key activities to achieve the TA output include (i) 
training needs assessment, (ii) training calendar, (iii) developing new e-learning approaches and 
innovative interventions throughout the project cycle, (iv) short training programs that are more 
needs specific, and (v) output monitoring systems. 
 
9.  A training calendar for 2013–2014 will be developed in consultation with the regional 
departments and will list all training events, with tentative target DMCs and dates, based on the 
finding  of  the  training  needs  assessment.  The  training  calendar  will  be  updated  regularly, 
circulated widely, and posted on the ADB website. This will enable executing agencies to plan 
staff participation in advance. The demand-based interface will ensure targeted interventions.  
 
10.  A review of COSO training content will be undertaken. The training materials will be 
updated, and more and updated case studies introduced. E-learning and other media, such as 
demand-based short procurement courses to support training needs, will be prepared and 
delivered to respond to requests from countries dealing with complex procurement issues and 
with fundamental constraints on understanding and contract project management processes. 
Procurement  capacity  assessment  initiatives  will  also  be  aimed  at  executing  agencies  in 
selected countries during loan processing. 
 
11.  All of the training content developed and delivered under the regional TA will be aligned 
with other ongoing training initiatives led by COSO and regional departments. The TA support 
                                                
6  The TA complements ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance for Developing Procurement Capacity for Improved 
Procurement Outcomes. Manila, which (i) aims to catalyze reform efforts in the government procurement function, 
and (ii) is a long term capacity development intervention at policy level. The TA ‘Enhancing Capacity for Effective 
Implementation’ aims at building the capacity of EAs staff on overall project implementation in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines. It is therefore a short/medium term capacity development intervention at project level.

will build capacity of less-experienced executing agencies currently or about to be involved in 
implementing ADB projects. The implementation experiences of different DMCs will also be 
shared through learning workshops and seminars. Emphasis will also be given to contract 
administration  training,  Fédération  Internationale  Des  Ingénieurs-Conseils  (International 
Federation  of  Consulting  Engineers)  contract  management,  and  training  of  trainers,  as 
appropriate. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The cost estimates and financing plan are 
in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB will be the executing agency of the TA. COSO’s portfolio management unit will be 
responsible for implementing the TA. Individual consultants will be hired to help prepare and, if 
appropriate, deliver the new courses. All consultants will be recruited by ADB in accordance 
with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The 
effectiveness of the program will be measured from the feedback of the participants. 
 
14.  ADB’s regional departments and resident missions will be the main channels used to 
engage  with  the  executing  agencies.7 A  selection  criterion  will  be  set  up  and  applied  in 
consultation with the regional departments. A range of new tools and resources will be used to 
support the capacity development needs of the DMC. Staff of executing agencies and resident 
missions  will  gain  knowledge  and  skills  on  project  implementation,  especially  related  to 
procurement of goods, works, and services in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2010, as amended from time to time) and Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). 
 
15.  The regional TA will be completed by 15 December 2014 (24 months). The TA will 
require 5 person-months of international consulting services and a total of 30 person-months of 
national consulting services (Appendix 3). Procurement specialists in COSO, and staff from 
regional departments and resident missions will provide support to TA implementation. This will 
include taking an active part in facilitating the trainings and supervising the training content 
updates where possible. ADB staff from COSO, regional departments, and resident missions, in 
addition to other resource speakers, as needed, will provide support to arrange and deliver the 
training. ADB’s resident missions will assist in coordinating logistical arrangements. 
 
16.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis 
for Enhancing Capacity for Effective Project Implementation, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board. 
 
                                                
7  No TA activities will be undertaken in a DMC until the DMC has provided its no objection to such TA activities.

Appendix 3  7 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Training Programs for Effective Project Implementation 
 
1.  Procurement Capacity Development Specialists (international consultants, 5 
person-months) 
 
1.  In response to comments and demands from user departments, resident missions, and 
executing agencies or project implementation units, the objective of the input is to prepare two 
or three practical courses on procurement topics critical to project implementation. The courses 
will contain real-life examples or case studies, such as methods of preparing and reviewing bid 
documents, or evaluating bid documents for civil works and supply contracts. 
 
2.  The specialists will undertake the following: 
(i)  review current training content, and revise and/or update as necessary; 
(ii)  in  consultation  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  Central  Operations 
Services Office (COSO), choose two or three critical topics for short procurement 
courses  and  identify  suitable  base  materials  from  previous  projects  or  from 
COSO’s procurement checklists to illustrate key issues; 
(iii)  prepare  country-specific  case  studies,  including  compendium  of  procurement 
cases  and  case  studies  from  simple  to  complex  which  can  be  used  as  a 
reference by ADB staff and executing agencies; 
(iv)  prepare training course materials with guidelines for the facilitator; 
(v)  pilot test the courses with COSO staff and modify them based on the feedback 
from participants; 
(vi)  prepare an assessment tool for monitoring the impact of the training; 
(vii)  document lessons learned in implementation in selected DMCs and how those 
lessons could be incorporated in other countries; and 
(viii)  participate in community of practice operations events when required. 
 
3.  Qualifications. The specialists should preferably have at least 5 years of related work 
experience.  The  specialist  should  be  familiar  with  project  management,  procurement,  and 
contract  management  and  administration  of  projects  funded  by  multilateral  organizations. 
Involvement  in  procurement  capacity  development,  including  procurement  training  and 
familiarity with ADB project and procurement cycles, is desirable. 
 
2.  Project Implementation Specialists (national consultants, 25 person-months) 
 
4.  Individual  national  specialists  will  be  engaged  to  conduct  capacity  development 
programs on ADB’s project implementation, particularly procurement and consultant selection 
procedures for government staff implementing ADB-funded projects in selected DMCs. The 
specialist may also provide mentoring support in preparation of necessary documentation at the 
project office. 
 
5.  The specialists will undertake the following: 
(i)  design the course content for the training program on ADB’s procurement and 
consultant selection procedures at project sites, as decided by ADB; 
(ii)  develop country-specific case studies for use during the training programs; 
(iii)  provide  on-the-job  training  to  executing  agency  staff  in  preparation  of  key 
documents such as standard bidding documents and bid evaluation reports; 
(iv)  prepare training materials;

8  Appendix 3 
 
(v)  collect  feedback  from  participants  and  staff  and  keep  records  in  prescribed 
templates as advised by ADB; and 
(vi)  participate in community of practice operations events, when required. 
 
6.   Qualifications. The specialists should preferably have at least 5 years of related work 
experience. The specialists should be knowledgeable in ADB procedures, and should have 
project  implementation  and  training  experience.  Involvement  in  procurement  capacity 
development, including procurement training and familiarity with ADB project and procurement 
cycles, is desirable. 
 
7.  The specialists will submit an inception report, a report at the end of each training 
program,  and  a  final  report  containing  feedback  from  participants  and  staff,  findings,  and 
suggestions for further improvement in the program. 
 
B.  Development of Electronic Training Modules 
 
1.  E-Learning Specialist (national consultants, 5 person-months) 
 
8.  E-learning will be used as a prerequisite before a nominated executing agency staff 
member can attend the training program. The objective of the e-learning module is to ensure 
that participants of the training events have at least an equal knowledge of the basic consulting 
and procurement modules. 
 
9.  The  specialists  will  design,  pilot  test,  and  implement  two  e-learning  courses  for 
consulting  and  procurement,  and  will  deliver  modules  on  CD-ROMs  and  help  upload  the 
courses to the internet. 
 
10.  The specialists will undertake the following: 
(i)  adapt into electronic format the training materials used in project implementation 
seminars, 
(ii)  develop interactive training modules incorporating case studies and exercises, 
(iii)   prepare  the  scripts  for  a  new  project  implementation  and  administration  e-
learning system with procurement and consulting modules based on the existing 
project implementation and administration course content,1 and 
(iv)  train COSO staff to maintain the e-learning modules. 
 
11.  Qualifications.  The  specialist  should  preferably  have  at  least  3  years  of  related 
experience, should be knowledgeable in ADB procedures, and have project implementation and 
training experience. The specialist should be experienced in designing, applying, and managing 
e-learning methods including content management systems, presentations, e-learning scripts, 
and e-learning systems. 
                                                
1  The  new  project  implementation  and  administration  scripts  will  deal  with  participant  registration,  course 
administration, virtual presentations, short lectures, quizzes, tools, links (with ADB’s URL), interactive activities 
(e.g., virtual case studies, illustrative exercises), course evaluation, provision of online certificates, and frequently 
asked questions. They should cover the project implementation and administration basics and provide links to sites 
that provide information about recent COSO developments and changes.
